name: 5-bromoindole
Reason: 5-bromoindole is a compound with a bromine atom attached to the indole ring. The indole ring itself has a melting point of 52-54°C. The bromine atom is a heavy halogen atom, which can increase the melting point due to its large size and high molecular weight. The bromine atom can also participate in London dispersion forces, which can further increase the melting point. The bromine atom is attached to the indole ring at the 5-position, which is a relatively unhindered position. This means that the bromine atom can interact with other bromine atoms in neighboring molecules, leading to stronger intermolecular forces and a higher melting point. The bromine atom can also participate in hydrogen bonding with the nitrogen atom in the indole ring, which can further increase the melting point. Overall, the presence of the bromine atom in 5-bromoindole is expected to significantly increase the melting point compared to indole.
